- Cercospora leaf spot is a fungal disease mainly occurring in the hot and rainy season across the country
- Check for disease symptoms on cassava leaves once per month
- Check for brown spots with a yellowish ring on leaves throughout the growing period of cassava.
- Look for lesions that are 0.15 to 0.2cm in diameter
- Consider control when 1-3 plants out of 10 plants in the field are affected.

- Remove most affected leaves (10 to 15 spots on the leaves) from the plant to reduce spread of the disease.
- Remove fallen leaves and debris from the field and burn them. Burning is usually not preferred in IPM, but a good option to prevent fungal spore carry over.

- The fungicides below are toxic to fish so do not mix, spray, clean near rivers or dispose container in water bodies (at least 50m distance)
- When using a pesticide, always wear protective clothing. Follow the instructions on the product label. Do not empty into drains.
- If disease persists after spraying with chemical, take samples to plant doctors for further advice.
- WHO class II pesticides might not be allowed in local IPM schemes.
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (ZEMA).

- Spray Carbendazim (Carbendazim, Assure, and others); a protective fungicide that inhibits mitosis and cell division. Cannot cure, but can prevent spread of disease. General Restrictions: WHO U (Unlikely acute hazardous). Pre-harvest interval (p.h.i.) 21 days; Re-entry Interval (r.e.i.) 1 day, thus after drying of spray
- Spray copper oxychloride products (such as Cuprozin 35WP, Copper Oxychloride, and many others). Multisite activity group of fungicide, with protective and some curative action. General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class II (Moderately acute hazardous); Do NOT spray more than 2 times in a growing season. Do not pluck leaves for use as a vegetable at least 7 days after spraying; p.h.i. 7 days; r.e.i. 1 day, thus after drying of spray
- Spay Tebuconazole products (such as Folicur C 300SC, Prosaro, and others). Systemic fungicide with some curative action. General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class II (Moderately acute hazardous) Do NOT spray more than 2 times in a growing season. Do not pluck leaves for consumption at least 21 days after spray; p.h.i. 21 days; r.e.i. 1 day after spray

Images.Caption: Brown cercospora leaf spots on cassava (E. McKenzie  Landcare research)
Light brown spot with with yellowish ring and fine dark outer ring (E. McKenzie)

Factsheets.Title: Cercospora brown leaf spot on cassava

Authors.Surname: Chella Musenga, Donald Mwaba, Valentine Kilubi, Kaponda Bwalya, Jacqueline Mweembe, Brian Siame, Mkulama  Mtawa, Robert Kelly Salati, Aggrey K. Chipuluka , Conwell Chilala, Demian Mabote Ndalamei, Kanyata Muchula, Isaiah Ntenga ( Ministry of Agriculture)

Sections.Value:
- Intercrop cowpeas with garlic to repel aphids
- Rotate with cereals like maize, sorghum, millet, or with onion.
- Do not rotate with groundnuts and not with legumes as they are also hosts.
- Remove volunteer cowpeas in the following crop as they will host aphids.
- Avoid using insecticides as they kill the numerous and usually effective natural enemies of aphids.

- Monitor cowpeas for aphids and lady beetles (natural enemies) from young plant stage until harvest every 2 weeks in the mornings
- Look for black or green tiny soft bodied insects (1 to 2 mm) on stems and the underside of leaves
- At heavy infestation, leaves may curl and have many aphids underneath.
- Look for honeydew (sticky substance) on leaves that comes from the aphids.
- If 5 to 8 young plants out of 100 plants have several leaves with many aphids, consider green direct control.
- If 10 to 20 young plants out of 100 plants have several leaves with many aphids, consider yellow direct control.
- If 10 to 20 flowering plants out of 100 plants have several leaves with many aphids, consider green direct control.
- If you find many ladybeetles, control may not be needed
- Close to maturation, only heavy infestations across the field may need intervention with direct control.

- Prepare a chilli water soap solution (12 chillies + few drops soap as a spreader per 10 litres water) and spray directly on aphids on the underside of leaves in late afternoon, and not in full sunshine.
- Spray neem tree extracts on to aphids on the underside of leaves. Pound 2kg of neem leaves & soak in 10 litre water for a day, add some drops of soap, then sieve before spraying.
- Spray with Tephrosia extracts. Pound 25 leaves & soak in 10 litres water for 1 day, add few drops (or 50 g chopped soft) soap, and spray.
- Repeat sprays after 2 weeks if needed.

- Aphids are often controlled by natural enemies. Thus only spray when aphid threshold is reached. Reach good coverage with the spray and make sure it reaches the underside of leaves and stems, as most insecticides work on contact only.
- When using a pesticide (even a botanical home-brew), always wear protective clothing. Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, pre-harvest interval, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval. Do not empty into drains.
- WHO class II pesticides might not be allowed in local IPM schemes.
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (ZEMA).

- Deltamethrin products (Pali, Decis, Netprotect, and others). Pyrethroid contact insecticide. General Restrictions: WHO Class II moderately acute hazardous, Toxic to bees thus do not use on flowering crop or near bee hives. Fish toxic. Pre harvest interval (p.h.i.) at least 7 days. Restricted re-entry interval (r.e.i.) 1 day. Maximum 1 spray per season.
- Cypermethrin products (cypermethrin, Viraat, and others). Pyrethroid contact insecticide. General Restrictions: WHO Class II moderately acute hazardous. Toxic to fish, avoid mixing, spraying cleaning near fish ponds. p.h.i. 14 days, r.e.i. 1 day. Maximum 2 sprays per season.
- Lambda-cyhalothrin products (Trigger, Boxer, Ninja). Pyrethroid contact insecticide. General Restrictions: WHO Class II moderately acute hazardous. Toxic to fish, avoid mixing, spraying cleaning near fish ponds. p.h.i. 3 days, r.e.i. 1 days. Maximum 2 sprays per season.
- Thiamethoxam products (Actaca, Renova, and others). Neonicotinoid systemic pesticide. General Restrictions: Not WHO classified, but considered to be slightly acute hazardous in normal use, Toxic to bees thus do not use on flowering crop or near bee hives. p.h.i. 21 d, r.e.i. 1 d. Max 2 sprays/season.

Images.Caption: Cowpea aphids: soft bodied, 1 to 2 mm (Infonet Biovision)
Bad leaf development due to aphids on cowpeas  (E. Phillips)
Heavy aphid attack (Infonet, Biovision)

Authors.Surname: Mathews Matimelo (ZARI), phone no +260977601065, email: yamiko2006@yahoo.com

Sections.Value:
- Plant using certified seed from reliable suppliers
- Rotate maize with non-cereal crops such as sweet potato or beans for a period of 2-3 seasons if MLND had attacked your or neighbouring fields
- Do not plant maize near fields with infested maize as the disease will spread into your field
- Avoid movement of green maize from infected areas to disease-free areas

- Maize Lethal Necrosis Disease (MLND) is expected to invade Zambia.
- Inspect fields weekly for vector insects and the disease symptoms.
- MLND-infected maize will not yield a cob, thus losses are high
- Look for yellow stripes on leaves which are much wider than those of Maize streak virus. MLND causes yellow stripes that later lead to drying, stunted growth, failure to tassel, no grain filling in cobs and death of the whole plant leading to the whole field having plants with dried appearance
- Angular leaf spot disease also causes necrotic dead leaf areas but only in spots and not entire leaf edges or leaves as for MLND
- Consider taking action as soon as few plants shows these symptoms
- Look for thrips (tiny yellowish-green slender insects) and leafhoppers (small 0.5 cm greenish insects, jumping) on leaves as they spread the disease.
- If planthoppers and thrips are seen on a number of plants you may consider action if disease is in neighbouring fields or has just arrived in your field.
- If many plants in a field show MLND symptoms vector control is too late.

- Report to the Ministry of Agriculture of any suspicions of MNLD since it has not yet been recorded in the country
- Immediately uproot and bury infected plants at least 5 cm, when seen in the field. Do not hesitate to do so, as plants will have no grains in cobs anyway.

- There are no pesticides against MLND
- Control the MLND - vectoring plant hoppers only if neighbouring fields are infested and yours not or little. This is because plant hoppers are difficult to control as they can re-immigrate into fields after spray.
- When using a pesticide, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, pre-harvest interval, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval. Do not empty into drains and water sources.
- WHO toxicity class II products may not be allowed in local IPM schemes.
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides of ZEMA of Zambia

- Apply malathion-based products to leaves (organophosphate). Usually at a rate of 20-30 ml/20 L but double-check label as products differ. General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class III (slightly acute hazardous); p.h.i. 14 days; r.e.i. 3 days; maximum sprays 2 times/season. Moderately toxic to aquatic organisms; Highly toxic to bees. Possibly carcinogen.
- Apply Deltamethrin-based products (pyrethroid) following the recommendation on the product label. . General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous), p.h.i. 3 days; r.e.i. 0.5 days. Toxic to bees and to aquatic organisms; To be applied only once per season (Alternate with other pesticides)

Images.Caption: MLND wide and narrow yellowing on maize (Stefan Toepfer)
Plants dwarf. Finally, the entire plant dries and dies (Stefan Toepfer)
Leafhoppers: greenish hopping insects 4mm, vectcors MLND (Lynett Elliot)

Factsheets.Title: Maize lethal necrosis disease in maize
ScientificNames: Maize lethal necrosis disease MLND (combination of two viruses, Maize Chlorotic Mottle Virus (MCMoV) and Sugarcane Mosaic Virus (SCMV) or other cereal viruses)

Authors.Surname: Mooya A.M Nzila, Zambia Agriculture Research Institute, Chilanga, mooyanzila@yahoo.com

Sections.Value:
- Plant barrier crops such as garlic or onion around the field to repel aphids
- Conserve the numerous and effective natural enemies of aphids by preserving natural flowering plants near fields and by not spraying broad spectrum pesticides such as Abamectin, Deltamethrin, Acetamiprid
- Remove non-flowering weeds to minimise early infestation of crop (some weeds harbour aphids), but keep long-flowering weeds to support natural enemies.
- Separate early and late planted fields to prevent movement of aphids from old to new plants

- Melon aphids easily multiply and also transmit plant viruses.
- Look for tiny 1-1.5mm long, soft-bodied, pear-shaped insects on underside of leaves and/or on stems, usually in groups
- Aphids may be light green, yellowish or dark green
- Look for stunted plants with yellowish, curled / distorted leaves when heavily infested
- Start a week after crop establishes and scout weekly for early detection
- Consider green direct control when 10-15 aphids found per young plant because aphids reproduce fast (see green direct control column)
- Consider chemical direct control when you see 30-40 aphids or more per young plant ( see yellow direct control column)

- Prune leaves showing heavy symptoms (curled, distorted, lots of aphids underside leaves) and smash
- Remove crop residues at end of harvest to prevent aphid transfer to new crop. But do not do this when there are only few aphids as residues improve soil and maintain water.
- Spray neem oil solution. Add 30ml neem oil into 250ml of liquid soap stir well. (Liquid soap/emulsifier-ensures that the oil and water can mix well). Add 1L water and mix well. Use the solution immediately. If not, the oil droplets will start floating. Spray with knapsack sprayer, early morning or evening
- Ensure even spray coverage especially underneath the leaf. Spray once in 10 days but at least 10-14 days before harvest to not poison the watermelon. Ask your local agro-input suppliers to organise such products if neem trees do not grow in your area.

- Spraying should be done before flowering because most pesticides are toxic the pollinators such as bees
- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, pre-harvest interval, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval. Do not empty into drains and water sources.
- WHO toxicity class II products may not be allowed in local IPM schemes.
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides by ZEMA in Zambia.

- Spray Acetamiprid -based products (such as Golan, Assail, Acetamiprid 20% SL, Bear). Systemic. Neonicotinoid group. General Restrictions: Not classified by WHO, but considered slightly hazardous in normal use. Restricted re-entry Interval (r.e.i.) 1 day; pre-harvest interval (p.h.i.) 3 days. Harmful to aquatic organisms and bees. Max. number of sprays =2, not consecutively
- Deltamethrin -based products (such as Deltamethrin, Keshet 2.5EC, Decis forte, and others) Pyrethroids group, contact pesticides that need good coverage-sprays. General Restrictions: WHO class II (moderately hazardous) ; r.e.i. 1 day, p.h.i. 7 days. Toxic to fish and bees. High risk to non-target insects including natural enemies. Max. number of sprays = 2, not consecutively

Images.Caption: Tiny 1.5 mm aphid adults is  is yellowish to green or black (Timothy A. Ebert)
Adult and young aphids yellow to dark green on underside of leaf (David Riley, University of Georgia, Bugwood.org)
Leaf curl (cupping) seen on cotton caused by many aphids (Ronald Smith, Auburn University, Bugwood.org)

Authors.Surname: Mooya A.M Nzila, Zambia Agriculture Research Institute, Chilanga, +260 966 728668  mooyanzila@yahoo.com

Sections.Value:
- Do early land tillage by end of October-early November, to reduce growth of the weed
- Use recommended fertiliser rates (200kg Compound D and 200kg Urea/ha) as over-fertilisation favours the growth of the weed
- Plant early with first effective rains of at least 30mm cumulative rain, thus before weeds germinate
- Use certified maize seed to avoid introduction through contamination by weed seeds in the maize grains
- Intercrop maize with legumes (beans, cowpeas) to allow complete ground cover to inflict negative shading effects on the Oxgrass (weed is sensitive to competition). For intercropping, plant maize at 90 cm X 90cm
- Avoid grazing animals in the fields as they spread weed seeds in animal dung

- Oxgrass is an invasive weed, producing more than 50,000 small seeds/plant, and competes with maize for water and nutrients
- Viable oxgrass seeds persist in the upper soil for 2-5 years
- Look for a tufted annual grass with lots of side shoot spreading upwards up to 40cm tall
- Leaves are bright green, flat to V-shaped or folded along main vein, up to 8mm wide and 15cm long. Leaf tip boat-shaped
- Thin flower heads have 3-8 'branches', each with two dense rows of tiny greenish flowers
- Scout fields weekly after crop emergence for presence of weed.
- Consider direct control methods when young oxgrass plants are found in 10-25 different spots of your field during sampling.
- Remove the weed when young by hand-pulling or hoeing. Later, the weed removal gets harder as roots grow stronger
- Preventive and green direct control measures are usually enough to control the weed, so there is no need of synthetic herbicides

Images.Caption: V-shaped Oxgrass seedling with a longer, acute, boat-shaped tip (Rebekah D. Wallace, University of Georgia, Bugwood.org)
Thin flowerhead consists of 3-8 racemes (branches), each 5-10 cm long (Chris Parker/Bristol, UK)
Tufted annual Oxgrass with leaves up to 8mm x 15 cm, glabrous (smooth even surface), bright green (Chris Parker/Bristol, UK)

Authors.Surname: Jacqueline Mweembe MOA +260977478715 mweembejay@gmail.com, Brian Siame MOA +260979611267 briansiame1@yahoo.com, Dorcas Kabuya MOA NAIS +260977439597 domucar@yahoo.com

Sections.Value:
- Remove weeds and residues in areas with powdery mildew history, as they may harbour the disease, and bury them far from the cultivated field.
- Crop-rotate with cereals, onion or garlic to break the disease cycle.
- Do not plant a nursery near the old diseased crop
- Spray a preventive fungicide in the rainy season if you had mildew problems in the previous year. Refer to direct control yellow column.

- Powdery mildew is a fungal disease and a problem in the dry and hot season.
- During the initial stage check for fine dusty whitish powdery fungal growth on the leaves 3 weeks after germination.
- When severe, leaves become yellow or dried and brownish. Stems can also be affected. Then actions are too late
- Monitor weekly when the crop is still young and at least once every two weeks when the crop is maturing.
- Action should be taken when 6-10 out of 100 plants are showing the initial spots of thin green-whitish powder spots on upper leaves.

- Prune heavily diseased leaves (bury at least 30 cm) to reduce spread of disease
- Pound 1.5kg of neem leaves and soak them in 16 litres of water for 24 hours. Sieve the mixture, add 50g of soft soap like SunlightTM and spray once per week but no later than 10-14 days before harvest.
- Use baking soda (potassium bicarbonate) mix 2.5 tablespoons of baking soda with 2.5 tablespoons of vegetable oil in 16 litres of water, add 2.5 teaspoons of soft soap like SunlightTM or LifebuoyTM as a sticker and stir. Spray on the leaves once in 2 weeks. Repeat if new infested plants occur.
- Use 9-10 tablespoons vinegar mixed with 16 litres of water and spray every 2 weeks

- Most fungicides are protective and thus reduce or prevent new infestation. They cannot usually cure an infested plant. If whitish powder is seen everywhere, treatments are too late.
- When using a pesticide (even a botanical home-brew), always wear protective clothing. Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, pre-harvest interval, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval.
- WHO class II pesticides might not be allowed in local IPM schemes.
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (ZEMA).

- Sulphur-based products. Inorganic multi side action pesticide. Usually at 120 grams per litre of water, but follow label instruction to avoid phytotoxic effects on crop. General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class III (slightly acute hazardous); Pre-harvest interval (p.h.i.) 10 days; restricted re-entry interval (r.e.i.) 1 day after spray. Max 3 sprays per season. Keep livestock out of reach.
- Spray copper oxychloride products (such as Cuprozin 35WP, coprus, copper oxychloride, Trust, others). Multisite activity group of fungicide, with protective and little curative action. Refer to the label for dosage information. General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class II (Moderately acute hazardous); Spray once per growing season; P.h.i. 7 days; R.e.i. 1 day. Fish toxic, thus do not mix, spray, clean near rivers or dispose or clean container or equipment near water bodies.
- Spray Cyproconazole products (such as Alto 100SL, Atemi, others); Protective fungicide that cannot cure, but prevent spread of disease. Check labels. General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately acute hazardous); Spray once per growing season. p.h.i. 7 days; r.e.i. 1 day after spray

Images.Caption: Whitish powder on upper leaves due to powdery mildew (courtsey of NAIS)
Dying leaves due to severe intestation of  powdery mildew on  an Okra plant (courtsey of NAIS)

Authors.Surname: Kilubi Valentine and Bwalya Kaponda (Department of Agriculture Siavonga &  Department of Agriculture Mongu),  phone no 0977400181, email vbkilubi@yahoo.com and k2bwalya@gmail.com

Sections.Value:
- Transplant by late December to early January before the outbreak of beetles
- Follow the plant recommended spacing of 5cm x 30cm to avoid overcrowding of plants.
- Remove alternative hosts like weedy grasses to reduce beetle food both in the field and 1-2 metres around the field.
- Rotate with a legume crop such as beans or cowpeas soon after harvesting (July to October) to break down the pest life cycle
- Destroy highly infected crop residues after harvest to cut the lifecycle of the beetle by deep burying or burning as the pest pupates in plant tunnels.

- Look for dead young rice plants at seedling stage both in nurseries and the main field due to chewing of leaf tissue by both larvae and adult beetles.
- Look for small shiny, blue-black beetles with tiny nearly invisible short spines over the body.
- Check every 2 weeks for 1-2 mm wide and 5.5 mm long pale yellow larvae burrowing into leaf tissue. Look for small larvae tunnels on leaves
- Consider green direct control measures when 5 to 10 adult beetles or larvae are noticed per 10m2
- If green control is not enough, consider yellow direct control measures when 10 to 20 adult beetles and/ larvae are noticed per 10m2

- Hand pick and crush adult beetles in plastic or paper bags depending on the size of the field and infestation levels
- Flood the rice fields particularly in young plant stage to chase away beetles by making their habitat unfavourable
- Place 5 blue medium size containers per lima filled with water and 2 to 5 teaspoons soaps (such as boom) to attract and kill the pest by drowning when 5 to 10 adult beetles per 10 square metres are noticed in the field.

- When using a pesticide (even a botanical home-brew), always wear protective clothing. Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, pre-harvest interval, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval. Do not empty into drains.
- WHO class II pesticides might not be allowed in local IPM schemes.
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (ZEMA).

- Spray Cypermethrin products (cypermethrin, Viraat, and others). Pyrethroid contact insecticide. Repeat spray after 10-14 days if the pest is still present at threshold. Read product label for dosages. General Restrictions: WHO Toxicity Class II moderately acute hazardous. Do not mix, spray, clean containers near rivers as it toxic to aquatic organisms (fish). Do not spray to Paddy Rice. Apply when crop is at seedling stage. Pre harvest interval p.h.i. 28 days; Restricted re-entry interval r.e.i. 1 day
- Spray Imidacloprid products (such as ATS Imidacloprid 200SL, Amigo GT, Ngwenya T450FS & Imidacloprid). Systemic neonicotinoid insecticide. General Restrictions: WHO Class II moderately acute hazardous. Do not spray on flowering plants or near bee hives as it is toxic to bees. Do not spray more than once in the season as it persists. P.h.i. 60 days; r.e.i. 1 day

Authors.Surname: Mathews Matimelo (Zambia Agriculture Research Station Institute), phone no.+260977601065, email:yamiko200@yahoo.com

Sections.Value:
- Buy certified seeds as they do not contain weed seed. In contrast, recycled maize seeds may contain seeds of the weed
- Do primary tillage to allow the weed to germinate quickly (two weeks after onset of rains). Then destroy it using secondary tillage
- Clean the equipment outside the field before use, as it may harbour the small seeds of the weed
- For small fields, use organic mulch form broad-leaved plant residues to suppress growth of weed and to conserve water

- Amaranthus is eaten as a vegetable but can also be a serious pest in maize and other crops
- Look for rough, soft, grey-greenish or green-reddish leafy plants with alternate leaves. Leaves are oval or diamond shaped and broader at the base
- Look for these weeds from germination of the maize (November to December) up to the time the maize is tasselling
- Monitor for this weed every after two weeks
- Check randomly for the presence of the weed from different parts of the field.
- Consider weeding when you notice that about 20% of the inspected parts show signs of the weed
- Since the weed produces a lot of seeds, it should be controlled before it produces seeds

- Hand-pull the Amaranthus weeds. You may use them as a vegetable.
- Remove weeds using a hoe
- Apply biological weed control using weed-disease causing bacterium, Erwinia carotovora var. rhapontici in collaboration with the Zambia Agriculture Research Institute
- This weed is successfully controlled by preventive and direct green control measures, therefore there is no need to use synthetic herbicides

Amaranthus producing numerous seeds (Joseph M. DiTomaso, University of California - Davis, Bugwood.org)

Authors.Surname: Mathews Matimelo (Zambia Agriculture Research Institute), phone no +260977601065, email: yamiko2006@yahoo.com

Sections.Value:
- Public awareness and encouraging famers to report outbreaks to Agricultural Ministries is a major initial step of prevention and control
- Avoid planting sorghum near water points as these birds like water areas
- Time the planting of sorghum so that it flowers at the same time as wild grasses which are preferred by the birds
- Cover sorghum heads with cloth or weaved grass or leave sheaths to protect from bird attack

- A flock of 2,000,000 birds can causes up to 50 tons of sorghum losses per attack
- However, the birds prefer seeds of wild grasses and only attack cereals when their preferred food is scarce
- Look for 10 to 15 cm small, short tailed birds with different amounts of black, yellow, pink, purplish or white feathers on the head and neck and different amounts of colouration on the belly among the moving in flocks
- These birds feed on the sorghum heads at the grain filling (February, March) stage of crop
- The birds can also be seen around November/ December feeding on the seeds that have just been planted
- Check daily for these birds from flowering stage to harvest as they can damage in a short period
- Consult the Department of Agriculture for updates on monitoring of the birds through ministrys early warning and forecasting system
- Consider action as soon as one flock is seen in the field

- Control of weaver birds is very difficult unless at small populations
- Put about 4-5 human dummies (scarecrows) per hectare to scare away small populations
- When larger bird flocks are around, scare birds using shouting, blasting, rattling with cans or throwing stones

- Control with chemical baits is done by the International Red Locust Organisation for Central and Southern Africa (IRLCO-CSA) through the Ministry of Agriculture. Therefore, farmers are advised to report presence of the birds the Ministry of Agriculture
- However, in IPM and on farm level any bird poisoning is not allowed, as risks are too high that beneficial birds (that eat insects) or even chicken are poisoned.

Images.Caption: Weaver bird (Santanu Sen, CC BY-NC-ND)
Many weaver birds (Chris Eason , CC BY)
Cover sorghum head with weaved grass to protect it from bird feeding (Ruelle and Brudggers, from: Traditional approaches for protecting cereal crops from birds in Africa)

Sections.Value:
- Avoid the use of infested plant materials. Before planting, cuttings can be treated using a warm water treatment. See the 'Warm water treatment of cassava mealybug' factsheet.
- If available, plant varieties that are less susceptible to the pest
- Plant healthy cuttings
- Plant early in the rainy season to allow the cassava plant to grow well, before the dry season, as strong plants are more likely to withstand pest attack
- Use soil amendments and mulch to avoid moisture stress in sandy or poor soils. Mealybug numbers are higher on cassava grown on poor soil, and may cause damage in spite of the presence of natural enemies
- Restrict movement of infested planting materials across borders or mealybug-free areas
- Avoid planting cassava for more than 3 years on the same piece of land. Rotate with maize and legumes

- Check crop weekly for mealybugs on shoots, stems and leaves
- The adult females and larvae will be visible on the stem and leaves. They are oval in shape, pinkish in colour and covered in a white, powdery wax
- Symptoms on the plant include stunting, wilting, leaf distortion, leaf fall, rosetting of the stem, bunchy top and dieback
- Ants may also be present as they protect the mealybugs and feed on the honeydew they produce
- Black sooty mould may grow on the leaves and stem in the presence of honeydew
- Take action when you notice white waxy material on shoot tips, leaves and stems or any signs of mealybugs

- Remove and destroy infested plants or plant parts at early stages of infestation. Burn cuttings if this practice allowed in your area.
- Prune stems or leaves with high infestation and burn or bury more than 50 cm deep
- Mix 5 g of soap (alata samina) + 5 g of powdered pepper in 1 litre of water and leave it for about 30 minutes. Pour the mixture into knapsack and apply in 15 litres of water
- Apply neem oil e.g. Grow-safe. Add 10 ml soap to 1 litre of water and stir to mix. Add 50 ml neem oil to the 1 litre water-soap solution and mix thouroughly. Add the oil-water-soap solution to 14 litres water in the knapsack and apply within 8 hrs. Ensure thorough coverage
- If possible, use natural enemies such as the parasitic wasp Apoanagyrus lopezi and ladybirds
- Control ants as these will reduce the amount of natural predators

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Mealybug damage to leaves and stem (R Reeder, CABI)
Mealybug infestation on a cassava stem (R Reeder, CABI)

Sections.Value:
- Rotate cabbage, rape, broccoli or cauliflower with any of the following crops: tomato, onion, maize, or sweet potato
- Plant early in the season to avoid the period of diamond back moth build-up
- Remove and bury/burn crop debris including weeds at least 4 weeks prior to sowing to reduce DBM population
- Plant seedling beds away from production fields
- Transplant only healthy seedlings free of eggs, caterpillars and pupae of the DBM and other pests
- Intercrop with tomato, chilies, marigolds or mustard. Mustard acts as a trap crop for adult moths. Plant two rows of mustard for every 25 of cabbage
- Slash left-over cabbage stems after harvest to avoid regrowth which can act as a diamond back moth breeding area
- After harvest, plough the field to expose any pests harbouring in the soil

- Additional relevant crops: Crucifer family (rape, broccoli, cauliflower, chinese cabbage)
- Inspect crop weekly, especially the underside of leaves
- Look for small, grey moths, which have a diamond pattern on their wings when at rest
- Look for caterpillars which are yellowish green to green and around 1 cm long when fully grown. They hang from a web when disturbed and tend to appear at the four leaf stage of cabbage growth
- Look for damage on leaves: irregular holes, windowing and skeletonised underside
- Detect DBM adults using pheromone traps, placing 2-4 traps/Ha. Check traps twice a week early in the morning. Use control when 5 + adult moths are caught in a trap
- Alternatively, you may consider direct control when you notice 2 to 3 young larvae per plant

- Uproot and bury or burn cabbage debris, if burning is permitted in your country
- Crush larvae by hand if noticed when numbers are few
- Apply aqueous solution of botanical pesticide neem or tephrosia (40g/L soak over night and seive)
- Alternatively spray chilli mixed with water and few chopped pieces of bar soap or drops of liquid soap
- Plant trap crops such as mustard and rape at the edges of the the field to reduce DBM attack
- Parasitic wasps such as Diadegma and Cotesia vestalis spp. can reduce DBM populations. See if these biological controls are available in your country
- Use overhead irrigation which dislodges the pest from the plant surface

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Sections.Value:
- Use clean pasture seed to reduce the chance of contamination
- Remove all existing hedges by cutting and digging out the roots (15cm depth)
- Move livestock out of previously infested fields. Sow land with pasture and/or native vegetation. Growth of new vegetation can outcompete the weed.

- Perennial woody shrub, 2-5m high, erect or scrambling.
- Branches with small thorns
- Leaves: yellow-green to green, rough, 2-12 cm in length
- Flowers: multicolored (yellow, orange, white, pale violet, pink or red), in dense clusters ca. 4 cm across.
- Fruits: round, fleshy, 2-seeded, each 5 mm wide, green turning purple then blue-black. Arranged in dense, round clusters
- Look out for this weed on disturbed land, plantations, forest edges/gaps, gassland, water courses, lowlands and gullies

- Do not control with grazing as the weed is poisonous to livestock
- Removal of small infestations may be possible by cutting and digging out the roots (15 cm depth)
- Remove flower heads prior to seed set to prevent further spread
- Slashing and burning can stimulate regrowth of the weed. Combine with other control methods
- Control will need to be repeated, potentially over many years as the weed is difficult to get rid of

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Sections.Value:
- Use tolerant crop varieties if available
- Where possible, cover small plants with transparent plastic (such as polytunnels) to prevent insects from laying eggs
- Weed out leguminous plants which can be alternative hosts such as sweet clover, Lathyrus, and many others
- Destory and bury the remains of broadleaf weeds as they can harbour leaf miners
- Deep plough crop residues

- Monitor weekly at all growth stages of crop
- Look for tiny thread-like tunnels (mines) on the upper leaf sides
- Look for larvae inside tunnels or on the upper side of leaves (tiny legless maggots with no separate head, whitish transparent and later yellow-orange)
- Threshold: At 8 to 12 infected plants per 100 plants, consider green direct control action
- Use glue traps or yellow sticky traps to see whether leafminers are present

- Hand pick heavily infested leaves with many leaf miner tunnels, and destroy them by crushing or burying them, or feeding them to cattle if palatable
- Spray neem extract against larvae onto leaves in the early morning or late evening. Add a sticker such as liquid soap to the neem water mix. Reach good leaf coverage. Neem slightly enters the leaves and reaches some of the larvae inside the tunnel
- If possible cover soil under infested plants with plastic sheets to prevent larvae from reaching the ground and pupating
- Use glue traps or yellow sticky traps to trap leafminers
- Biological controls of leafminers include parasitoids (e.g.Chrysonotomyia punctiventris and Ganaspidium hunteri), nematodes (e.g. Steinernema carpocapsae, bacteria and fungi

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Sections.Value:
- Minimise the level of nutrients in water by limiting fertilizer use
- Use of containment fences across the waterways to prevent introduction of weeds to paddy fields
- Use water from tanks free form Salvinia

- Evergreen, mat-forming, free-floating fern, branching horizontal stems (up to 625 cm long and 1.2 cm thick), submerged feathery roots
- Leaves: Green or yellowish-green fronds, in pairs, oval (26 cm long and 1015 mm wide); almost impossible to wet due to a covering of fine egg-beater-shaped hairs (13 mm long) on upper surface; undersides covered in matted brown hairs.
- Flowers: none
- Fruits: None, reproduces from detached fragments
- Look out for weed in drainage ditches, irrigation channels, dams, ponds, swamps, wetlands, lakes and slow-moving rivers

- Manually remove weed if infestation is small
- Biological control options include the salvina weevil, Cyrtobagus salviniae. See if they are available in your country

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Sections.Value:
- Use tolerant crop varieties if available
- Where possible, cover small plants with transparent plastic (such as polytunnels) to prevent insects from laying eggs
- Weed out leguminous plants which can be alternative hosts such as sweet clover, Lathyrus, and many others.
- Plant maize around beans because maize acts as a barrier against the leaf miners
- Rotate beans with cereals, and not with legumes, tomatoes, garlic, onions, groundnut, rape, melon or cucumber.
- Tomato is a host plant for L. trifolii

- Monitor weekly at all growth stages of crop
- Look for tiny thread-like tunnels (mines) on the upper leaf sides
- Look for larvae inside tunnels or on the upper side of leaves (tiny legless maggots with no separate head, whitish, transparent and later yellow-orange)
- Threshold: At 8 to 12 infected plants (with 5-6 infected leaves) per 100 plants, consider green direct control action
- If, after green direct control, leaf miner damage still increases up to 20 to 30 infected plants per 100 plants, then consider chemical action
- Use yellow sticky traps to assess the presence of L. trifolii

- Hand pick heavily infested leaves with many leaf miner tunnels, and destroy them by crushing or burying them, or feeding them to cattle
- Spray neem extract against larvae onto leaves in the early morning or late evening. Add a sticker such as liquid soap to the neem water mix. Reach good leaf coverage. Neem slightly enters the leaves and reaches some of the larvae inside the tunnel
- If possible, cover soil under infested plants with plastic sheets to prevent larvae from reaching the ground and pupating
- Use yellow sticky traps to reduce numbers of L. trifolii
- Parasitoids, and to a lesser extent to nematodes, bacteria and fungi, are used for biological control of leafminers

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

L. trifolii visible within the leaf mine (NBAIR)

Sections.Value:
- Keep density of crop high in order to shade out the weed (it grows poorly in low light):
Plant crop before weed germinates in late summer
- As seeds can travel on animals and machinery, do not allow animals into an affected area, limit machinery use in the area and keep machinery clean to prevent spread

- Annual or perennial creeping herb; produces seed above and below ground.
- Leaves: oval to lanceolate; short hairs when young; 3-7 cm long, 1-2.5 cm wide (length up to twice width only)
- Flowers: three lilac blue petals; 3-4 mm long - lower is smaller than other two and sometimes white
- Fruit: pear-shaped capsule; five seeds (sometimes appear sugar-coated; grey-brown)
- Stems: short hairs when young
- Distinguished from other species in its genus by: all three petals blue; leaves broadly elliptical (length up to twice width only); rough, ribbed seeds; presence of stolons; leaf sheaths with reddish-brown tipped hairs
- Keep a close eye on row cropping systems such as peanuts, soybeans and corn - these types of crops are favoured by the weed
- Prefers wet soils but can survive for long periods without moisture. Particularly likes disturbed land.
- Take action as soon as weed is seen

- Uproot by hoeing or hand-pulling. When removed, shake off soil, spread out and dry for more than a week
Cut stems can resprout. Stem fragements must dessicate to a moisture content of 50% for a period of 30 days to prevent resprouting
- Moldboard plough more than 1 inch below surface
- Use conventional tillage as supposed to strip tillage (do not use minimum tillage systems)
- Note: emphasis should be given on preventive and mechanical measures as extreme tolerance to glyphosate has been documented.

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Sections.Value:
- Prevention measures are particularly important as this weed is difficult to control. Tubers are the main means of spread;
Clean tools and farm machinery to prevent introduction to new fields
Do not accept potentially contaminated materials, e.g. soil on planting stock
- Plant highly competitive cover or cash crops such as jack bean, velvet bean, bush bean, soybean, cotton, chayote and cucumber.
- Narrow crop row spacing can help prevent the establishment of the weed by shading it
- Control established populations near waterways to prevent spread during flooding and storm events

- Erect, perennial sedge (30-60 cm high), with extensive underground network composed of tubers
- Tubers dark brown/black, irregular shaped, 1-2 cm long at maturity, with several buds
- Leaves linear with distinct midrib, 7 mm wide
- Flowering stems 3-sided, erect. Inflorescence with several unequal 'branches', each 2-6 cm long, emerging from the tip of the stem; each with 3-8 purplish-brown flowerheads

- Destroy tubers and rhizomes in the soil via dessication (most effective in dry soil) or exhausting food reserves
- Cultivate every 2-3 weeks until crop canopy forms: the weed is shade intolerant
- Plough and cover an infested area with a polyethylene sheet to destroy tubers and rhizomes in the dry season (soil solarization). This can be very effective but not always 100%.
- Place organic mulch over areas where weed is expect to grow to provide temporary weed suppression
- Tillage must be deep (> 12cm) in order to disturb as many of the rhizomes as possible. Do this every three weeks and under dry conditions so the exposed rhizomes dessicate.

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Whole plants (S.D. Sawant)

Sections.Value:
- Purchase certified crop seed and animal feed to reduce the chance of contamination
- As seeds can travel on animals and machinery, do not allow animals into an affected area, limit machinery use in the area and keep machinery clean to prevent spread
- Keep crop healthy to maximize competitiveness - use optimal water and fertilizer levels
- Limit the amount the tillage where D. stramonium is present. Post-harvest tillage may promote survival since seeds become buried
- Do not allow livestock to graze on sparse pasture where weed is present. Livestock otherwise may eat the poisonous weed

- Bushy annual herb; 0.5-2 m tall
- Seedling leaves: oval-shaped, pointed tips, few or no lobes
- Mature leaves: oval to broadly triangular-shaped, unevenly toothed
- Stems: green to purplish, stout
- Flowers: trumpet-shaped, white to creamy or violet, rarely completely open
- Seed capsules/cases: egg-shaped, walnut-sized, spiny or bald
- May be confused with other species within the Datura genus:
D. stramonium: 100 or more capsule spines; long flower (up to 10 cm) D. ferox: up to 60 capsule spines; shorter flower (4-6 cm)
D. stramonium (and D. ferox): straight capsule stalks; black or grey seeds. D. leichhardtii, D. metel, D. inoxia and D. wrightii: curved capsule stalks; brown or yellow seeds
- Monitor open and disturbed areas particularly closely. D. stramonium can be found on roadsides, agricultural land and riverbanks.
- Take action as soon as weed is seen

- Dig, pull or hoe out before seed sets in order to prevent it spreading. Wear gloves when handling it since it is poisonous, particularly its leaves and seeds. Be thorough since it can regenerate from root fragments if not removed effectively
- To dispose of pulled weed, if seed has not set, add to a compost heap. If seed has set, ensure pulled weed is buried to least 60 cm/2 ft, or burn it to prevent spread (if permitted in your country)
- Till the soil when weeds are seedlings. When mature, stems become woody and difficult to remove
- Grow winter annual crops and forage crops and cut them several times during the year to control the weed
- Remove weed before making hay, silage, grain or other animal feed to prevent spread
- Seedlings emerge over a long period of time so repeated removal may be necessary

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Sections.Value:
- Purchase certified crop seed and animal feed to reduce the chance of contamination
- As seeds can travel on animals and machinery, do not allow animals into an affected area, limit machinery use in the area and keep machinery clean to prevent spread
- Keep crop healthy to maximize competitiveness - use optimal water and fertilizer levels

- Creeping, perennial grass, rhizomatous; 50-100 cm high
- Leaves: flat; bluish-green 15 cm long, 2-8 mm wide
- Inflorescence: 2-25 racemes. Spikelets in pairs
- Rhizomes: can be over 1 m deep in soil forming dense mats
- Fruits: elliptical in various shades of light brown, grey and purple
- Looks similar to Cynodon dactylon, but C. dactylon has a membraneous ligule where the leaf blade joins the sheath

- Use a forked hoe to remove rhizomes. Ensure removal is thorough to prevent resprouting
- Till land to expose and dessicate rhizomes, but be aware that this action may also spread fragments which can grow new plants
- For coffee, plant Guizotia abyssinica and Linum usitatissimum as cover crops to suppress weed

Sections.Value:
- Purchase certified crop seed and animal feed to reduce the chance of contamination
- As seeds can travel on animals and machinery, do not allow animals into an affected area, limit machinery use in the area and keep machinery clean to prevent spread
- Keep crop healthy to maximize competitiveness - use optimal water and fertilizer levels
- For pasture, encourage good grass coverage since grass can outcompete the weed. Limit the amount of grazing in a particular area:
Supply multiple watering points to prevent livestock congregating
Rotate livestock between paddocks

- Tufted annual grass, spreading or stands straight, up to 60 cm tall
- Seedlings: first leaf is about 1 cm long, pointed, may lie flat on soil
- Leaves: bright green; smooth; flat to V-shaped; up to 8 mm wide, 15 cm long. Tends to form a long-growing rosette with white-coloured leaf sheath at the base
- Flowers: arranged in clusters of 3-5
- Does not root at nodes of growing stems.
- Seeds: reddish-brown to black; oblong; ridged; about 1 mm long
- Roots: centralized system; very strong when mature
- Spreads along disturbed habitats such as roads and powerline corridors. Look for it along marshes, stream banks and coasts
- Can be confused with weeds such as Digitaria, Dactyloctenium, Cynodon, Chloris or Paspalum spp. E. indica is distinguished by the combination of its flattened stem, bright green leaves, size and many-flowered character of spikelets, lack of awns.

- Remove by hand if the weed is smaller than 5-8 cm in diameter. Use a hoe if removal is difficult. Removal gets harder as weed grows (root system is stronger)
- Till the land. The weed grows best in compact, poorly drained soils so make sure it is aerated and drained
- Use solarization to kill weed seeds down to 5 cm. This requires watering (light irrigation) of the soil area after mulching and before covering the area with the transparent polyethylene sheet
- Use shredded newspaper as a mulch on tomato fields
- Use a rye cover crop its residues should supress the weed

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Sections.Value:
- As seeds can travel on animals and machinery, do not allow animals into an affected area, limit machinery use in the area and keep machinery clean to prevent spread
- Do not allow livestock to graze in infested pasture seeds can pass through digestive tract unharmed
- Clean shoes, clothing and hair after being in a potentially infested area. The bristly one-seeded pod segments are sticky
- Ensure uncontaminated water is used when flooding rice paddys as pod segments float and can be transported by water

- Regularly check sites such as machinery tracks, grazing places, previously flooded areas fallen dry for seeds and any seedling establishment
- Check for any seed germination at the start and end of the wet season
- Spreading, multi-stemmed, thorny shrub usually up to 2 m tall,
- The inflorescences, containing up to 100 flowers, flowers are pale pink and arranged in fluffy, globular clusters (10-20 mm across)
- The fruit is an elongated and flattened pod covered in bristly hairs and up to 15 cm long and clustered at the stem tips
- The plant is evergreen and bears bipinnate (twice-compound), sensitive leaves, up to 18 cm in length. When touched they fold together and also during the night
- Recurved spines (to 7 mm long) are located on the undersides of the petioles, petioules and stems

- Uproot plants by hand-pulling or using machinery, and destroy roots
- Collect seeds and burn before weeding
- Cut plants off at 10 cm below ground level to kill the weed. Use long handled cutters, axe or machete:
Blade ploughing is effective since it cuts below ground level. Slashing and chaining alone is not (requires herbicide application afterwards)
- Burning is not recommended does not prevent resprouting and kills only surface seeds. It may stimulate germination. Also reduces the numbers of the stem-mining moth Carmenta mimosa
- Check which biocontrols are available in your country. Examples of biological controls include:
Beetle species such as Acanthoscelides puniceus or A. quadridentatus
The green twig-mining moth Neurostrota gunniella attacks mature plants and seedlings greater than 15 cm (should not be used in Thailand or Vietnam). You can use this after weed removal to reduce herbicide use
- Fragment infestations to increase numbers of control agents such as N. gunniella since it increases weed stand edges

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Sections.Value:
- Purchase and sow certified crop and pasture seed to reduce the chance of contamination
- Seeds are spread by animals - do not allow livestock into an affected area to avoid spread
- Seeds travel on machinery - clean equipment and vehicules after work in infested areas
- Prevent spread of Sida by slashing or mowing before it flowers
- Avoid overgrazing to prevent establishment of the weed in disturbed patches

- Small shrub (0.5-1.5m) with lanceolate leaves with dented egde.
- The flowers are yellow, solitary, 1-2 cm in diameter and on a short stalk 0.3-0.8 cm long. Each flower has six petals and produces seeds with two awns, thus attaching easily to animal fur
- The fruit is a hard, brown capsule, 3-5 mm in diameter, breaking into 5-8 triangular segments
- Regularly check waste and other ruderal sites, because these are usually the first invaded by Sida
- Check for flowering and seed development to prevent seed set, spread and build up of seed bank

- Dig up single plants prior to onset of flowering, ensuring the taproot is severed well below the crown to prevent regrowth
- Plow or hand-weed after the first rains have induced germination, followed by sowing of dense pasture or cover crop
- Larger areas can be controlled by repeated cultivation until the soil seed bank is depleted
- Competitive grasses may be effective in suppressing Sida, when combined with other control measures

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Flowering shoot (Chris Parker/Bristol, UK)
Infested area (S.D. Sawant)

Sections.Value:
- Clean material, boots, clothing and vehicles when moving out of infested areas
- Seeds are spread by animals - do not allow livestock into an affected area to avoid spread
- Species is spread by water - use only water from sources free of the weed and avoid runoff from surrounding infested fields
- The species is spread by wind - limit seed set in surrounding populations
- Mulching using plastic sheeting or wood shavings reduces establishment from seed

- Annual or perennial herbaceous broadleaved shrub, woody at the base [23 (5) m high]
- Leaves greyish-green, finely hairy on underside giving a grey appearance. Simple, 35 (7) pointed lobes (633 cm long and 522cm wide)
- Flowers bright yellow, daisy or sunflower-like (up to 10 cm across), carried on long and swollen stalks (730 cm long)
- Regularly check fields for presence of the weed and consider direct control when present
- Check for flowering and seed development to prevent seed set, spread and build up of seed bank

- During the rainy season, regularly cut the weeds before flowering. Either chop plants into pieces and heap them within the hedge to dry and decompose of feed to livestock
- Hand-pull and destroy the weeds emerging in the crop field, ensuring the taproot is severed well below the crown to prevent regrowth. Allow them to dry and decompose or feed them to livestock
- Do not slash the plants, as plants can regrow from cut fragments
- Consistent follow-up work is required for sustainable management

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Flowers are bright yellow, up to 10 cm across (John M. Randall, The Nature Conservancy, Bugwood.org)
Leaves have 3-5 pointed lobes (Arne Witt, CABI)

Sections.Value:
- As seeds can travel on animals and machinery, do not allow animals into an affected area, limit machinery use in the area and keep machinery clean to prevent spread
- In pasture, encourage the health and abundance of desirable plant species to make the ecosystem more resilient against invasion

- Upright, branching, annual herb; shallow rooted; up to 1.5 m tall
- Stems: become woody with age; young parts have short white hairs
- Leaves: Egg-shaped, toothed, sparsly hairy, rough, 2-10 cm long, 0.5-5 cm wide
- Flowers: Purple, blue, pinkish or white; less than 0.6 cm across; clusters of flower heads at top of stems; few hairs on bracts surrounding flower heads; projections (styles) of 0.5 cm (gives fluffly appearance); flower head base 0.5-0.8 mm across
- Seeds: Germinate in response to light; viable for 12 months.
- Similar to Ageratum houstonianum which has: numerous sticky hairs on bracts surrounding flower heads; shorter flower projections (styles) of 0.1-0.2 cm; smaller flower head base (0.3-0.6 cm)
- Look along waterways. Seeds are mainly spread via wind, water, on the hair of animals and attached to clothes and agricultural machinery
- Take action as soon as weeds are identified

- Short periods of flooding (water stagnation), for at least 10 days, can reduce weed density and mass
- Use minimum tillage systems such as strip tillage as this reduces weed density
- Can be easily uprooted mechanically as roots are shallow. Do this before weed flowers
- Increase fallow length in slash-and-burn rice production systems to reduce weed mass
- Spread infested ground with thick mulch and leave undisturbed in order to smother the weed

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Sections.Value:
- Purchase and sow certified crop and pasture seed to reduce the chance of contamination
- Seeds are spread by animals - do not allow livestock into an affected area to avoid spread
- Seeds are spread on clothes and shoes - remove seeds when leaving an infested area
- Species is spread by water - use only water from sources free of the weed and avoid runoff from surrounding infested fields
- Avoid overgrazing to prevent establishment of the weed in disturbed patches
- Prevent spread of the weed by slashing or mowing wfhen they are still small
- A maize-bean intercropping system can effectively suppress the weed
- Use thick mulch with dry non-weedy plant materials to prevent germination of the weed

- Annual erect broadleaved weed (up to 1 m high) with green composed leaves and a strong taproot
- White flowers with yellow centre and 1 cm long black seeds with 2-4 yellowish awns at one end
- Check fields and surroundings for presence of weed once a week during early crop establishment, and once a month later
- Check for flowering and seed development to prevent seed set, spread and build up of seed bank

- Dig up or hand pull plants prior to onset of flowering, ensuring the taproot is severed well below the crown to prevent regrowth
- Mow or slash the species prior to flowering and seed set
- A no-seed threshold is important as it prevents further spread of the weed

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Sections.Value:
- Remove and destroy (burn) the remenants of previous crop
- If available, use a resistant variety of maize
- Plant early in the season at the onset of rains when leafhopper (MSV vector) populations should be lower
- Avoid planting crop downwind of, or next to, an infested crop
- Maintain a barrier of 10 m of bare ground between maize fields and previously infested crops
- Keep field and neighbouring fields weed free, being particularly careful to remove grassy weeds on which leafhoppers can live
- Apply fertilizer on time, basal dressing at planting and top dressing on knee high maize. Maize will grow fast and be more resistant to infection
- Mix-crop maize with non-grassy/ non-cereal crops like cowpea and pumpkin to reduce leaf / plant hoppers.
- Leave barriers of bare ground or edges of non-grass vegetation between early planted and late planted maize to prevent leafhoppers crossing from late planted to the early planted maize
- Rotate maize with non-cereals such as legumes e.g. soyabeans and beans.
- Avoid the overlap of two maize crops

- Additional relevant crops: oats, barley, wheat, rye, sugarcane, sorghum
- Look out for:
Leaves: pale spots or flecks, 0.5 mm in diameter. Initial pale (white to yellowish) spots may join together to form longer streaks. These streaks are narrow, more or less broken, running parallel along the leaves
Leaves: Hopping insects on the underside (leafhoppers). These carry MSV
Whole plant: Stunted with small cobs if infection happens before the 4-5 leaf stage
Flowers and shoots: Possible abnormal bunching
- Monitor plants at least weekly from seedling to vegetative stage, particularly when there is high rainfall since this is when leafhopper populations can be high
- Take action as soon as one plant shows disease symptoms
- When there are 3 to 10 leaf hoppers on 100 plants it is likely that the disease will spread if existing in the area. If MSV is not in the area, no action is needed against leafhoppers
- Note the difference between maize lethal necrosis disease (MLND) and MSV. MLDN has thicker yellow stripes along leaves than MSV and can cause necrosis. MSV usually does not lead to necrotic dead leaves
- If yellow-grey angular spots or necrotic grey windows appear on leaves, then this is angular leaf spot disease, not a virus
- Remove infected plants at an early stage - uproot and burn or feed to livestock

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Plants affected by Mazie streak virus (Eric Haraman)
Streak virus symptoms on maize leaves (PM Kodwaran, Kenya)
Adult leafhopper, a vector of MSV (NBAIR)

Sections.Value:
- It is essential to control bean fly during the first four to five weeks after germination as it causes high economic yield loss in the seedling stage, especially during the dry season:
- Plant early in the season, 3-5 days after the onset of the rains
- Mulch with dry banana leaves, grass, rice straw and other similar plant straw to promote root development and enhance tolerance to maggot damage
- Don't plant leguminous crops next to each other such as common beans, cowpea, soybean, mung bean and peas
- Ridge up the soil around the plants to cover the roots 2-3 weeks after germination to allow roots to grow more quickly
- Encourage natural enemies presence in the fields by planting flower stripes and by not using pesticides
- Remove and destroy volunteer crops
- Frequently irrigate to reduce water stress and strengthen plant to better tolerate the bean flies
- Crop rotation with non leguminous crops
- Avoid overlapping bean crops in the season to reduce build-up

- Additional relevant crops: cowpea, soyabean, pigeon pea, common bean, mungbean, peas
- Look for small black flies of 2 mm on bean leaves from plant emergence up to 2-leaf stage of plants
- Look for tiny yellow feeding and oviposition punctures on the basal portion of the upper side of leaves
- Stem: Search for thickening of the stem at soil level which is made by the the fly larvae feeding inside. Upon cutting the stem open, a brown or dark feeding area of damaged tissue can be seen just underneath the epidermis. This portion will contain larvae and pupae.
Whole plant: yellowing, wilting, stunting and dying of young plants (2-3 leaf stage)
- Take control measures when 5-10% of the plants are infested

- Uproot and burn withered and dead infested plants to kill the larvae and pupae
- Spray using neem-based products early in the morning or late evening on the plants
- Remove and destroy crop residues as maggots and pupae live in the bean stems.

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Adult Ophiomyia phaseoli (James Litsinger)
Leaves show feeding and oviposition punctures on the upper side with corresponding light yellow spots (James Litsinger)
When attack is severe, infested leaves become blotchy and later hang down. Leaves may dry out and be shed (James Litsinger)

Sections.Value:
- Bag immature fruits with polythene, paper or silk clothing within one month of flowering
- Harvest fruits at physiological maturity before they become very ripe and soft which makes it easy for the flies to lay eggs in them
- During harvesting, collect infested fruits in black polythene bags, tie them up and expose to sun or bury infested fruits more than 50 cm deep in soil in order to kill larvae and prevent infestation in the next season
- Prune regulary to improve aeration
- Release poultry in the orchard to feed on pupa at the base of plants

- Additional relevant crops: guava, citrus, melons, avocado, pear, mango, banana
- Adult fly: B. dorsalis is about 8 mm long, wings about 7 mm in length, colour is variable - may have yellow and black markings
- Larvae: B. dorsalis is about 10 mm in length, creamy white, forms a dark brown puparium when it matures and emerges from fruit
- Regularly observe fruit trees for adult fruit fly at fruiting stage
- Check for egg-laying holes ('stings') on the surface of the fruits. These holes may be indicated by oozing or dry sap
- Sample fallen fruits and dissect them for fruit fly larvae which are small white maggots
- Set 10 pheromone traps per ha. A catch of 2-3 adult fruit flies per trap per week necessitates control measures (see 'Pheromone traps against fruit flies in citrus' factsheet)

- Apply neem oil or neem seed extract to kill pupating larvae
- Store harvested fruit in cool place or cold storage for 5 days

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Fly larvae (=maggots) in a grapefruit (Eric Boa, CABI)
Pupae of B. correcta, note scale (S.M. Jalaluddin/Sugarcane Research Station, Tamil Nadu Agricultural University, India)

Factsheets.Title: Fruit fly on fruit trees
ScientificNames: Bactrocera dorsalis, Bactrocera kandiensis, Bactrocera correcta, Bactrocera tau, Bactrocera zonata

Sections.Value:
- Use clean cuttings from certified sources. Mealybugs can travel long distances on cuttings.
- Use tolerant varieties if available
- Do not plant near an infested field. Mealybugs spread locally via wind and walking
- To prevent the spread of the insect, avoid rotating or planting near alternative hosts; citrus, avocado, carambola, fig, guava, sugarcane, cassava, mango, asparagus, beans, beets, cabbage, peanuts, pigeon pea, cucumber, lettuce, pepper, pumpkin, tomato

- Look for plant symptoms:
Stunted growth at growing tips
In susceptible plants, new growth forms cabbage-like clusters of leaves or may cause crumpling of the leaves
Distorted leaves and possibly defoliation, bunchy top
Sooty mold on leaves and stems
- Look for the mealybugs (they can be found on leaves and stems):
Eggs: tiny, pink
Crawlers (young): 0.3 mm long, pink/greyish-pink, covered in a white powder
Adults: 2.5-4 mm long, soft-bodied, elongate oval, slightly flattened. Males have one pair of wings and long antennae.
- Ants 'farm' the honeydew secreted by mealybugs so they may be found on and around the plants
- The pink hibiscus mealybug can look similar to Paracoccus marginatus, but P. marginatus is has a yellow body rather than pink
- Use the mealybug ladybird Cryptolaemus montrouzieri, or parasitoids Anagyrus kamali and Achrysopophagus sp. as biological control if available in your area

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.
